assertion.description: Web Service. A service implementation implements the methods of an interface that is describable by WSDL. The methods are implemented using a Stateless/Singleton Session EJB or JAX-RPC/JAX-WS web component. Add support for Singleton Session EJB.
Web Service Components. The second uses a constrained implementation of a stateless session EJB or Singleton(only for JAX-WS services) in the EJB container. Add support for Singleton Session EJB.

JAX-WS 2.2 adds a complete Web Services addressing support as specified in Web Services Addressing 1.0 - Core, Web Services Addressing 1.0 - Soap Binding, and Web Services Addressing 1.0 - Metadata. Add support for all these Web Services Addressing specifications in Java EE 6.
Interoperability Java API for XML-based Web Services (JAX-WS) 2.2

Web Service Server View. Add support for Singleton EJB. The service provider implements the JAX-WS Web service business logic by creating a singleton Bean that implements the methods of the Service Endpoint Interface as described in the EJB 3.1 specification.

Support for Jakarta EE profiles. The Java EE 6 platform specification introduces "profiles" to target specific class of applications.
The Java EE 6 platform marks JAX-RPC as a proposed optional technology that may be pruned in a future release. Therefore, requirements in this specification related to JAX-RPC should also be considered proposed optional. Such requirements may be made optional in a future release of this specification.
This specification gives choices for the vendors that want to support only certain containers for JAX-WS web services. A JSR-109 implementation must support at least one of the following configurations for JAX-WS web services:
1. JAX-WS web component in a Servlet container 2. Stateless or Singleton Session EJB as JAX-WS web service
